results.title: Trench coat man
results.creator_credit: Charles Skoutariotis, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Charles Skoutariotis talks about the events in his life, the little things, that led him to become the person he is. At school, they call him ‘Trench coat man’.

results.title: My neice
results.creator_credit: Samantha Sharp, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Samantha Sharp may have become an aunty early in her life but she’s glad she is. She plays with her niece in the way that older aunts couldn’t and she cherishes the time they spend together.

results.title: The Most important question in the world
results.creator_credit: Paul Young, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Paul Young went to university, he knew he didn’t want to be a teacher. However, over time, he has seen the value of the profession and learnt that it’s not about the content, it’s about the life lessons.

results.title: For the love of...Lolo
results.creator_credit: Ayen Guinto, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Ayen Guinto lost her beloved ‘Lolo’, her family lost the glue holding them together. She remembers him and wonders if the family should use his life as inspiration to move forward.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ayen Guinto, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Bittersweet
results.creator_credit: Maria Savarino, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When the train from Beijing to Lhasa started running again, Maria Savarino and her husband took the opportunity to visit Tibet before it had changed forever. What they found there was a bittersweet experience they will never forget but also never revisit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Maria Savarino, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: When the train from Beijing to Lhasa started running again, Maria Savarino and her husband took the opportunity to visit Tibet before it had changed forever. What they found there was a bittersweet experience they will never forget but also never revisit.

results.title: My life as I live it
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kit Guyatt, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Australian Film Commission
results.description: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.

Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.

results.title: My survival as an Aboriginal
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions
results.brief_description: After being forced from their tribal grounds, the Murrowarri were dumped onto a tiny reserve on the fringe of a white town. In this film Essie Coffey, black activist and musician, shows the conflicts of living as an Aboriginal under white domination. This film is part of her effort to make her community proud of their black identity while struggling to survive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alec Morgan, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Goodgabah Productions
